messageBody:
hi
 
I'm new to the JUnit approach, and am trying to implement
a unit testing methodology for an e-commerce framework that
my team has been working on.
 
I have already downloaded & set up Junit, and have written
unit tests for the self-contained parts of the framework (utility
& wrapper classes.. etc..)
 
What I am completely stuck on is how to extend this unit-testing
approach to efficiently test the business-logic component layer.
I understand that I need to set up a test-database, and will need to write 
set-up & tear-down procedures to reset the data each time we run
the tests (etc), but I need to find an efficient way to do this, since
the number of test-cases will be immense. I would like to try and
avoid using the EJB / Servlet JUnit extensions - since these
really apply more to the database-connectivity & presentation layers
of the framework, and I feel that it would be much more consistent to
use a regular version of JUnit to test the business-logic layer. I have
been told that JUnit++ simplifies some of the things that I will need to
do by using Properties that define a testing schema for me - but I have
yet to see a good example of this approach (something that tests classes
that interact with each other and use JDBC or something similar).
 
Are there any resource that i can peruse to find REAL examples of test
classes written for JUnit, JUnit++, or some other extension with testcases
for database related processing (but without a bunch of servlet/session testing) ?
 
Furthermore - to be specific - I am working with Oracle's BC4J (Business Class Objects for Java) for implementing the database-connectivity layer, and the business logic components
use BC4J components to talk with the actual Oracle database. Has anyone else
here had any experience testing such a framework with JUnit?
 
any help or guidance would be very appreciated
thanks / truly yours
Gary Bogachkov
Consultant
